introduction.p: In this chapter we define exponential and logarithmic functions. For a more extensive treatment of exponential functions we refer the reader to PreCalculus at Nebraska: Exponential Functions and for a more extensive treatment of exponential functions we refer the reader to PreCalculus at Nebraska: Logarithmic Functions

subsection.title: Exponential Functions
subsection.p: Before we discuss exponential functions, it is first useful to define the notion of concavity.

assemblage.title: Concavity
assemblage.p: The graph of a function is concave up if it bends upward as we move left to right; it is concave down if it bends downward. (See the figure for four possible shapes.) A line is neither concave up nor concave down.

subsection.p: An exponential function will be either concave up everywhere! We define such an exponential as follows:

assemblage.title: Exponential Function

p.me: P(t) = a(b)^t \text{, where } b \gt 0 \text{ and } b \ne 1 \text{, } a \ne 0.

assemblage.p: The constant a is the y-value of the y-intercept of the function.

subsection.p:
The equation
P(t)=P_0 a^t
gives an exponential function with base $a$. Then
\frac{P(t+1)}{P(t)}=\frac{P_0 a^{t+1}}{P_0 a^t}=a =\text{constant rate of growth/decay}
Growth: a\gt1: Doubling time: the time it takes to double the initial amount
Decay a\lt1: Half-life: the time it takes to decay to half of the initial amount

ul.li: The doubling time of an exponentially increasing quantity is the time required for the quantity to double.
The half-life of an exponentially decaying quantity is the time required for the quantity to be reduced by a factor of one half.

subsection.p:
We will (naturally!) consider exponentials (and later, logarithms) in base
e \approx 2.718281828459... \text{ (irrational number)}
For example, the general exponential function in the natural base
P(t)=P_0 a^t=P_0 (e^k)t=P_0e^{kt}, \quad a=e^k.
Thus, we will have
exponential growth if a\gt 1, which gives k\gt 0
exponential decay if a\lt 1, which gives k\lt 0
The number k is called the continuous rate of growth/decay. To find k we will need the logarithmic function.
